Only the upper most lock would be filled using lake water.   The plants would supply plenty of electrical power for the country in general, plus power for the lock pumps.  Concurrently, build a massive rail system across Panama to connect two large shipping ports as an alternative path.  Ships can unload containers on one coast to cross the country by continually running rails to the opposite side and be reloaded on another  container ship. 23:30 why did the build a highway? I mean sure, tolls on trucks may be easier to enforce than tolls on trains, i don't know, but a trucking route degrades faster than rails, takes more manpower, has to have rest stops for the drivers which cannot drive without pause, which isn't as large of a problem for train drivers, and it's less space and energy efficient. Rail can be a true competitor to shipping, volume wise, trucking cannot. If we take ten thousand containers per ship (largest is around 14.500) that is ten thousand trucks and drivers needed, if they manage to double containers per truck somehow, it's still five thousand. If we take 740 meters per train (longest allowed in germany), that is about 35 wagons per train, with, at most, 4 persons, 2 drivers, 2 engineers, and if they run modern, electrical engines, speeds that go up to 120 km/h (allowed maximum in germany again). As trucks are normally 80 km/h (again, allowed maximum in germany), they could transport a lot more cargo with trains than with trucks, and that even electrical, if they wanted to. Making this corridor a highway is hella inefficient.

What if there was some kind of massive shipping "handoff" operation in Panama that could reduce pressure on the Canal. Basically - docks on either the western or eastern coasts where ships carrying "handoff cargo" meant for continuation through to a route on the other coast is delivered. A fleet of semis (or even by rail, if viable) keep going back East-to-West-to-East to move the hand off cargo across land to the other side to be picked up by a ship receiving the "handoff" cargo to continue on to the rest of its journey. As the smartest guy in the world, a couple of things have occurred to me. I'm not an engineer (although I do have some technical skills), just the smartest guy in the world. It occurs to me, as you open the sea level lock, the seawater outside the lock might not immediately mix with the water inside the lock. When you let water from above flow into a lock, that water might not immediately mix with the water already in the lock. If the water was added in the correct way, a gradient would form and the freshest level of the gradient could be the part that was pumped back up to the higher level.  The end result is, the problem of ultimately pumping salt water back up to the lake might not be the issue people think it is. For another thing, the whole system could be periodically flushed. For another thing, when the fresh water supply was not stressed, there would be no need for any measure. Some of the solutions to the Panama Canal problem include: (1) Build a new, sea-level canal nearby.  Nicaragua is looking at this.  (2) Increase the water in Lake Gatun by pumping from a lower elevation. Both solutions are horribly expensive, but may have to be addressed before too long.

@litchar You can't pump water back up the locks without gradually raising the salinity of the lake, since each level mixes with the next whenever the ship crosses, so you have to dump some freshwater for the system to work. The problem with the Panama Canal is in its design not accounting for the waste of fresh water due to the oversight brought on by the historic abundance of fresh water. However (and as stated in the video) with climate change that abundance is now in doubt, and the lack of a no loss supply system to the locks have proven to be a dire design flaw. One way of mitigation would be create a new water systems management capacity, to use salt water and fresh water separately in their own distinctive lock supply buffers where the majority of the water is saved in reservoirs between leveling events. That is, instead of allowing fresh water to be lost into the lower locks with each leveling event, salt water is pumped in and then released back into the sea. However, to use such a system would require a tremendous amount of energy as gravity now feeds fresh water into the lock system (which is then lost after, which is the major cause of the issue). To use salt water to provide the lift, it would mean salt water must be pumped into the locks at tremendous energy costs. That would solve the issue for Panama, but maintain Canal dependence on the trade routes of the world. The optimal solution is to have several options so that world trade is not dependent on any single method.

Not only would the costs be justified in just a few years after the new canal would be opened, it would save annual costs of pumping water. Since pumping water would no longer be necessary. Just thinking through the geometry. You definitely got something wrong regarding shipping weight.  The amount of water needed to change elevation is smaller the more displacement the ships have. Because the larger ship is taking up space on the lock that would have to otherwise be taken up by water to get the elevations from one lock to the next to line up. Each lock is a fixed volume and the elevation change from ocean to lake is a fixed number for any particular ship.  The only way that less ship displacement would correlate with lower water use per ship is if the ships were smaller in plan area and there were a parellel set of locks with a smaller plan area. to use for them. Its also possible that lower loads are happening but you got the reason for it wrong. For example if the water level in the upper lake is too low to float ships with a deeper draft because the channel is not dredged deeply enough.

12:50 is wrong.  The load restrictions (actually draft/depth restrictions) are due to the water levels in the lake.  In fact, the amount of water required to raise the level of the ship is fixed at the loch surface area multiplied by the total elevation difference and entirely independent of the ships size and weight.  It's not intuitive but if you have a measuring cup that holds 2 cups and you want to raise it from the 1 cup line to the 2 cup line you have to add 1 cup of water, it doesn't matter if you have rubber duck in it or if you fill the bottom half with sand first, you still have to add 1 cup of water to move the water level up.

Part of the original plans for the Panama Canal included, placed alongside the locks, great cement pools, aka water holding tanks, wherever water from the locks could be pumped out as needed to lower water in a lock and held in the tank then, when the water in the lock needed to be raised that same water could be pumped back.  This, along with auxiliary pumping systems that would replace any water level in the retaining pools that was lost through leakage in the locks, or evaporation, etc, although that was expected to be minimal.  That system was planned for construction once the canal was in operation and making enough money to pay for that construction was designed along the lines of many of the lock systems in European lakes and rivers, especially in Germany and Austria.  The reason for holding tank for water at each lock meant that very little water would be required from the ecosystem, the lakes, and none would be just pumped into the oceans and lost, as the water for operation would be used over and over again.  By the time the canal was at the point of paying for the construction of the tanks, control of the canal had changed and the capital that had been held for that purpose was felt to be needed for other things, or seemed to just drain away, and those in control saw a canal functioning just fine without reusing and recycling water at the locks.  Given the billions the canal has mad one would assume that, better late than never, as they now have the evidence as to why there had been  plans, when thr canak was originally designed to eventually recycle water as the planners knew that the water in the lakes would have seasons where they could not supply  fresh water all time, that they would have now started this construction but the money to do this seems to be always directed elsewhere. Containers already do move east and west across the continental US, and rail companies have been complaining for years that they are under utilized. Re Colombian railways, there used to be a connection between the railways on both sides of the country. This was the Ferrocarril de Antioquia, which ran from Puerto Berrio on the Magdalena River (and a connection with the line to the Atlantic Railway) through Medellin to a connection with the Pacific line north of Pereira. However, a mix of corruption, incompetence, the trucking lobby and the violence of both the drug and guerrilla wars put paid to that by wrecking the whole Colombian railway system. The same goes for the line climbing from La Dorada (end of the present Atlantic network) to Facatativa over La Tribuna Pass then on to Bogota. The tracks are (mostly) still there hidden under the heavy brush, the line hasn't seen a train for the best part of 30 years. Rather a pity as the final ascent of La Tribuna was, judging from film footage, nothing short of spectacular, to the point that the Colombian Railways actually built Vista-Dome coaches in its shops to operate over the section, the only ones in Latin America and possibly the only narrow-gauge (3ft) ones in the world.

The solution is simple.  Instead of dumping the 52 million gallons of fresh water from the final lock back into the ocean, pump it back to the reservoir, thus lowering the water level of the final lock without releasing any fresh water into the ocean.  Clearly a far easier and less costly solution than building the canal.  It would likely slow the speed on the final of the 6 total locks ships go through between the two oceans and it would cost some electricity.  But creating a water pipe capable of moving 52 million gallons in maybe 10-20 minutes seems achievable.

I can "fix" the Panama Canal.  Proposal 1  One of the earliest plans for the canal was a sea level crossing.  The expense of that plan got it rejected, and the existing canal was the winning proposal.  The costs of digging out the sea level crossing have fallen, and that plan could be revisited.  Proposal 2  Each crossing "costs" 52,000,000 gallons of water.  Stop it.  No seriously, stop it.  Two options for ending the use of water: 1 don't let gravity do the work.  Use pumps to pump the 52,000,000 gallons up from the lower level to the upper level (except maybe the top level, to reduce the salt contamination in the lake). 2 have a pool next to the lock.  Don't drain the water from above, or pump from below, but use a water pool per lock for the water source, and the pumping "costs" are reduced and the water source is maintained local to the lock.  This eliminates contamination, and reduces water use for minimal extra power.  Proposal 2 option 2 is the most practical, as it uses 100% of the existing canal, but with enhancements to limit water loss.  Proposal 1 is the most sustainable, with zero additional power use, and, all being sea level makes the maintenance easier, but would take the equivalent work of making an all new canal, just within the space of the current one.  I would do #2(2) to stabilize it now, and begin work on #1 for a more permanent solution.  But nobody asked me.  Unfortunately, I expect Panama will run the existing canal without improvements until dead, then wait for some other country to swoop in with trillions of dollars to fix it for them.  For doing nothing is always the easiest option.  It just usually results in failure.

We produce pump out 25 million gallons of salt water from an aquifer a few hundred feet deep and desalinate it through high pressure reverse osmosis filters a day. It requires 8x 200 hp electric motors. They would likely need 500 such pump motors to deal with the logistics of this issue, basically just call it 1MW of energy per hour when you factor in elevation and other loss, although it could be a lot less with clever engineering. You would need at least a small power plant, to deal with the pump issues. You could recharge the lakes with filters, but the hypersalinated water would need to be ejected in the lowest lock and could have environmental issues on the coast.

12:45 What ?! Lighter ship cause less water displacement -> that's right. "and require less water to move through the locks' ? WTF ? no !? how would that even make sense ? The displacement of the ship doesn't matter. A light ship and an heavy ship will both enter the lock at the same elevation and you need to add the same amount of water into the locks to make them move up. Which is basically a give amount of m3. Since water is for this purpose "incompressible" the actual weight of the ship doesn't matter ! An explanation for this restriction is the water level on the lake. Since the lake water level is low, they do not want the ship to touch the bottom. Cause depth is linked to the weight and displacement. Also additional point, there are no pumps, it's literally like any other locks in the world it's gravity fed water from the high level to the low level. Also there are multiple sub-level tanks visible from the images next to the locks. Those are used to prevent too much water loss.

5:28 The narrator uses the word "pump" to describe the way the water is moved from one lock to the next. This is a bit misleading as the water is just released through valves, meaning the water can only follow gravity down to the next lock. Only being used once as it travels from the lake to the ocean. The video eluded to this, but if you didn't already know the system it was not very clear.  Using pumps to move water up to the next lock could be a partial solution, but the energy and time to move the amount of water to have any noticeable effect would be substantial.

As commented above, no water is pumped in the Panama Canal, it's all gravity fed. The new set of locks are hugely larger that the original set, to take much larger ships, but they use 7% less water. 60% of the water in the new locks is reutilized and never leaves the system.  When talking about all of the different projects in other countries, what you didn't mention in the video is that Panama has two Canals; one wet and one dry. The Dry Canal is a very efficient container cargo train that joins the ports on the Pacific Ocean and Caribbean Sea (there is no Atlantic in Central America). The Dry Canal train transports goods across the 80 km isthmus much faster than any of the options in other countries, and has been running for many years, so all the logistics and other issues are well-proven.  To increase the water capacity of the lakes, Panama is looking at options for more reservoirs. As mentioned in the video, the vast majority of the population of Panama is near the Canal, and the sites of proposed dams and lakes are in low population density areas.

A lot of comments about pummping the water back up and reusing it.  It takes about 1kwh to raise 325k gallons  1 foot.  The water would have to be raised about 80 feet, so for easy math 80kWhs.  That's about 12800kWh per ship.    @ 40 ships a day, thats 512k kWh per day, ~187m kWh per year.  These are aproximations, and I'd be glad of anyone willing to check the math.   Not sure how that converts to MW per year, so no idea how big a plant you'd need to run that.

"Because it works completely differently than other canals around the world do."  Uh, no. Differently how?  This system has been in use around the world for centuries.  The Grand Canal of China, which was begun in 540 b.c. and opened in sections over the next 1,800 years, remains the longest artificial waterway in the world as well as the oldest still in use.  It is a summit canal; that is, it follows the contour of the landscape. The changing terrain required boats to go up and down hills, so a system of locks were introduced.  The first to be built were flash locks, followed by the first pound lock in 983 CE.  The first pound lock in Europe was built by the Dutch in 1373, at the junction of the Utrecht Canal with the River Lek at Vreeswijk. It used guillotine gates, which move up and down to open and close. Around 1500 CE, miter gates â€” thought to have been invented by Leonardo da Vinci â€” began to appear in Italy.  The historical Panama Canal is just a container-ship-sized set of paired pound locks with mitre gates, while the expanded canal has rolling gates.  Building it certainly was a feat of engineering, but it doesn't really work any differently from other canal systems.

I can not speak on the engineering, but I know the forest contribute the the charging of the aquifers and reservoirs there. The world also had a strong El Nino and particularly La Nina the past few years arguably these conditions were made worse from climate change. Some of you may agree or disagree with that last part. But rivers were drying up all over recently globally and the jet stream has been unusually wavy.  Either way the canal is an exercise in a system with inflows and outflows, The rain is the inflow which pools in the lakes. And we expend that water as an outflow to move ships. Agriculture, evaporation, and residential use are also outflows. So long as the inflows are greater than or equal to the outflows then the system remains stable. We can manipulate the system by trying to increase the inflows and or reservoirs, or reduce outflows. Reforestation might capture and attract more rainfall, larger lakes can hold more water. We can also try to install a feed back loop that would pump water back up stream however while this could work it would be at the expense of and additional input cost "energy" as you would need to pump water uphill so it may or may not be worth it.     My take on it.

The Panama Canal locks are NOT operated using pumps.  Valves next to each gate are opened to allow water to pass between adjacent locks, and gravity equalizes the water levels.  Then the valves are closed as the gate is opened.  Pumps are just a needless opportunity for mechanical failure, and would be a tremendous cost to do something which gravity already does for free.

There's nothing unusual about the operation of the canal as shown. Reservoirs and flights of locks are standard features of canal systems. The water isn't "pumped" from the upper chamber to the lower in such a system. Gravity does the work. The new locks pump water out and pump it back in to conserve water, but that's not what shown or described.  One unusual feature at Panama is the first lock is flushed out with a flow of fresh water before closing to bring a ship up. This is to avoid bringing too much salt up into the lake, and it uses up a lot of fresh water.

Why don't they just do the incredibly obvious thing of pumping the water up to the lock above with water from the lock below? Youâ€™re wrong about the reduced amount of cargo reducing the amount of water used. The draft (the ships depth in the water) restricts the amount of cargo/ depth. If a ship were perfectly square, the same size of a lock,, minus an inch or two,  it would require mere tonnes of water to lower or raise it. If the draft/weight is reduced, it requires an equivalent amount of water on top of the reduced cargo to lift or lower the ship. Reduced cargo is increased amount of lake water used.
Interesting Fact about the Panama Canal. During WW2 when Countries like Japan were building the largest Battleship of all time (Yamato) the United States largest Battleship designs were limited by the width of the Panama Canal. So the United States largest battleship was the (Iowa Class Battleship) instead of building wider was built longer. The Iowa Class Battleship was a full 24 feet longer than the Yamato.  This extra length made the Iowa Class much faster than the Yamoto. Iowa's could travel up to 37 MPH meanwhile the Yamoto top speed was 31 MPH.

The value of the Canal to Panama is exactly what will keep it from "dying".  It is valuable enough to Panama that it would be feasible to install a pumping & desalination system: pump water from the ocean, take out the salt, pump it into one of the two reservoirs. There's plenty of unused land around the Canal for solar power, too.  Some back-of-napkin numbers indicate that it would cost about $7 billion to to build a plant that would pump/desalinate the entirety of the water usage. But conceivably, rainfall isn't going to drop to zero any time soon, so figure about $3 billion. This is not beyond the capability of the government to do, especially to protect and even *enhance* an asset that brings in more than $4 billion/year.  You could plan a modular $7B plant, but build it incrementally by adding one pump/desalination/power module as needed, to keep yearly costs low.

The Panama-Canal's greatest boon is also it's greatest drawback. That is it's reliance on Lake Gatun. Having the lake saved them the building of additional locks and blasting through mountains, but also makes the entire systems reliant on the lake's water level (as shown in the video). The Suez Canal by comparison doesn't has that problem because it runs on the saltwater that enters through the locks on either end. Of course doing that in Panama would make Gatun saline and ruin the freshwater source for the citizens of the country. The only feasible way to fix this that I see is too decouple the lake from the Canal system and have it run on saltwater without affecting the lake's salt content.

Am I stupid or does it make zero sense to require lighter loads to "reduce water displacement" in the canal? The way my reasoning works, the more water displaced, the less remaining volume in the canal that needs to be filled with water.  On the reverse side, if you imagine sending a rubber ducky through you have to move the entire canals volume of water with zero displacement, and you use it all for comparatively little cargo.

Let's say it takes 52 millions gallons per ship now. By doubling the steps count (in ideal state) they would be able to reduce the consumption to 26 million gallons. But it would require further doubling to reduce it by 13 more millions. And there may also be limits given by the length of the canal. Moreover, it would require a downtime of the canal itself.

For people not familiar with the maritime trade, a few numbers. Panama canal fees today for an average container ship with 15,000 TEUS is $5mln, including a hefty water surcharge. That comes to $300 per container, a substantially higher price than what it was just a couple of years ago. If the Tehuantepec option were to be used, unloading and loading each container at the other end would cost $200, or $400 for both and the railroad portion would be some $200-300, totalling $600-700!  Were numbers different, the project would have been done years ago. Likewise the simple idea of unloading cargo in Santos and trucking it for 1,500mi or 2,400km is simply absurd. At $0.10 per km that is $240 per ton. A ship will take that same ton from one corner of the globe to the opposite for less than a third of the price. Rail over long distances cost half as much as by truck, still grossly uneconomical. 90% of the worldâ€™s cargoes go by sea, and for good reason. It can be done for half a penny per km. 1/20th of the truck rate, 1/10th the rail rate. For non time-sensitive cargoes, absolutely nothing beats the ship. Nothing. And this is for containers. For break bulk cargoes, like cereals, iron ore, fertilizers, coal, the difference is yet more lopsided. For bulk liquids like petroleum or chemicals, even more. And for LNG (liquid natural gas) it simply cannot be transported other than by ship.

17:01 "Unlike the the problem, in the Red Sea that the US and UK are currently trying to solve with bombs, jets, and warships, The problem can only be solved..." - I think you underestimate the potential of bombs, jets, and warships to open up a choke point, assuming we don't care about collateral damage. On a less silly note, the Drake Passage is continually mentioned as "viable" but mostly restrictive due to the 18-day difference in transit time. This is not the Cape of Good Hope. The Drake Passage is way too dangerous. Your graphics and notes should include the Strait of Magellan. It's a small passage through Chile from the Southern Atlantic to Pacific, but avoids the majority of dangerous weather and currents that the route around Cape Horn is known for. The Strait of Magellan gets much narrower than the Bab Al-Mandab, but Chile and Argentina aren't waging a war here. It's plenty large enough for big ships, because many ships already transit here.  Tl;dr the Strait of Magellan is viable but adds three weeks or so to the journey. The Drake Passage is not viable. The storms make it a fool's journey for shipping. Braving Houthi missiles is probably safer.

A land bridge will never be a viable alternative to the Panama Canal for a lot of reasons. Loading/Unloading ships is time-consuming and usually takes a minimum of a day. Trucks simply aren't viable because you'll need thousands of trucks running around the clock. Rail in Mexico is the best option, but at that point, you can just divert North American cargo using rail links to the US/Canada instead of loading it back onto a ship.  A land bridge requires coordinating 2 ships on each coast, which isn't ideal. Then you have the smuggling problem, which is probably one of the biggest issues. The Panama Canal is ideal because the containers are safely secured on a ship. As soon as you take it off the ship, the container is vulnerable to looting or being used for smuggling because it's so hard to manage thousands of containers. Even in the US, container security is a big issue that gets worse every year. People have no idea how bad it is. Containers usually have at least 100k worth of goods with minimal protection, which makes it a very attractive target.

Its interesting that the solution Panama thinks about is just drilling for more water. Instead a modern approach would likely be to actually utilize the canal similar to how energy storage in reservoirs works in Europe. Basically you can get energy with turbines when the water is released from a higher reservoir to a lower reservoir and then put energy in to pump water from a lower reservoir to a higher reservoir. The efficiency is very high with losses of up to 85%. So potentially the water could be pumped back up again with investment of energy (which will increase costs, but likely less than building a new canal or huge new reservoirs). Most of that energy could however be regained if the water that is passing through the levels of the canal is used for energy gain (if that is not already done).. But clearly a good functioning railway would also work out, I am not sure why it has to be in Mexico though and not simply right next to the already well developed region of the Panama canal.

Summary: There is an unprecedented crisis happening in global maritime trade due to problems at two critical chokepoints - the Bab el-Mandeb Strait leading to the Suez Canal and the Panama Canal. Hundreds of missiles fired by Houthi rebels in Yemen have caused ships to avoid the Bab el-Mandeb route. Meanwhile, severe drought in Panama has led to water shortages that are forcing drastic restrictions on ships transiting the Panama Canal, causing major delays.  The crisis at the Panama Canal is caused by historically low rainfall failing to replenish the lakes that supply water to operate the canal's locks system. Climate change and the El NiÃ±o weather pattern have disrupted Panama's usual rainy seasons. The canal may continue facing reliability issues if drought persists.    With ships facing weeks-long waits to transit the Panama Canal, some are opting to take longer alternate routes around South America or Africa instead. But conflict near the Suez Canal is disrupting that route too. The bottlenecks are increasing costs and exacerbating global inflation.  There are several infrastructure proposals to build alternative trade routes across the Americas that could rival or complement the Panama Canal, including roads and railways across lower South America, an inter-oceanic train across Colombia, and an inter-oceanic corridor in Mexico. If realized, these projects could reshape trade flows and reduce reliance on the Panama Canal.    To remain competitive, Panama may need to invest in expanding the canal's water supply and make it more drought-resilient. However, climate change threatens to undermine the canal's reliability long-term, benefiting alternative routes. Controlling the critical chokepoint may not guarantee Panama's dominant economic position this coming century.

Worth mentioning that the canal is useful and can save millions of $ (and many, many lives of crew members) because Cape Horn is the most dangerous and vioent stretch of ocean on the planet. Many ships that go through there face unreal waves (sometimes surpassing 15-20 meters of height) that travel very fast and are incredibly steep that badly damage the ships and their cargo if they are container carriers, without mentioning the enormous weight that the ice adds to them, as water is sprayed by the waves and immediately frozen all throughout the ships, making them very unstable and prone to sinking.  The clash of the currents from the Southern Ocean with the South Atlantic combined with the immensely powerful winds create some of the most unique and destructive waves on the planet.  Once you go in, you can't turn around, you simply have to proceed. The weather can go from extremely bad and dangerous to straight up deadly in a matter of minutes with no warnings.  The horrific stories that many seafarers have to tell about that passage are heart wrenching to say the least, many of them thought they wouldn't make it out alive because the conditions were just SO bad.  So yeah, it is a very dangerous place to go through, you really do NOT want to go through that passage unless you absolutely have to.
Lets quickly take note again that this is a consequence of CLIMATE CHANGE and climate change only. This problem was forseeable for at least 20 years, and like all the other consequences of climate change, couldve been largely avoided. And its not the last consequence of climate change were gonna be facing. On top of it being bad, it also makes things worse: Shipping emissions are among the highest sources of all CO2 emissions (about 3%). By losing these shortcuts, these emissions will rise and worsen all climate change consequences. This seems like a problem that could be solved by better water management. It seems silly to say that the issue is a drought when you have oceans of water on either side of the canal. With plenty of water on either side of the canal, the issue shifts from being a shortage of water to being a surplus of salt. If you could devise a method for moving a ship from a tank of salt water to a tank of fresh water and back, using as little fresh water as possible, you could potentially reduce the amount of fresh water used by the system to a point where mitigating the lost fresh water with desalination becomes feasible. There is so much commerce that travels (or could potentially travel) through the canal that it seems like there should be enough financial incentive to bring all sorts of solutions to the table. We should be trying to decide which solution would be most beneficial rather than throwing our arms up in the air and blaming climate change (that's not to say climate change isn't to blame, only that blaming climate change doesn't solve the problem).

Just for grins - I did some googling.  The largest oil pipeline pumps I could find on a quick online search can move 40,000 barrels per day and cost $1,000,000. To move 52 Million gallons is about 1 million barrels - so  25 such pumps and 25 12" diameter pipes to send water from the bottom lock back up to lake level at the top rather than releasing it into the ocean would be sufficient to pass one ship per day.   To do one ship per hour - would require an alarming 600 of these pumps working at once(!!)- about what a typical long oil pipeline requires - at a cost of $600 million - which is peanuts.  Doing that would eliminate 100% of the water requirement from the lakes.   We don't need to eliminate 100% - so it seems like 50% would be more than enough.  So 300 large pumps and a lot of large diameter pipes probably isn't a whole lot of money to save the canal.   Build a big solar farm next door...solves the energy cost of doing it.   For about a billion dollars - you'd be good to go.   Why is something like this not being considered?

You can't take 70 years of data and conclude that climate change caused the current dry period.  The driest recorded time in US history was in 1930, long before any artificial climate change would impact the weather.  It is EXTREMELY likely that this would have happened regardless of climate change, and the impact of climate change on weather patterns is completely speculative at the moment.  There simply isn't enough historical data in most areas to tell the difference between a definitive change in climate and normal occurrence of extreme weather.  Even without climate change some weather patterns only repeat after hundreds of years.  Climate change also is much more likely to increase rainfall at these latitudes.  It is known that the Sahara is only a desert because Europe cooled off reducing moisture levels in the air that circulates into Africa.  The same effect would be seen during an El Nino with air coming down from North America instead of the Pacific Ocean.  Warmer air carries more water so a warmer climate will carry more water towards the equator (result of the Coriolis effect)

Much of the modern global economic system is built on a few key assumptions: 1) Sea transportation of goods is cheap, plentiful, safe and relatively quick. 2) Investment capital is plentiful and will go wherever a profit can be made. Neither of these assumptions was anything close to true for the vast majority of human society. Hyper concentrated, long-supply-chain systems as the way most things are produced is a modern phenomenon. We are seeing the limitations of those assumptions grow every day. How about we use a bit less stuff and make it closer to home? Most people in North America actually already own too much stuff. Buying a bit less, paying a bit more, and having it made close to home would be a good thing.

The panama canal could be re-built to double the number of ships passing through using the same amount of water. Currently, the locks can only be run in one direction at a time so when ships are going up, the level of the locks are changed with no ship in the lock when the level is lowered. If the locks were separated by a small lake, big enough for two ships to pass they could run ships in both directions simultaneously so that the locks never changed level without a ship in the lock, doubling the throughput without using any more water.  BTW, the reason they are limiting the cargo on the ships has nothing to do with the amount of water used, the same amount of water is used to change the level of the locks when a fully loaded ship is in the locks, or completely empty. The reason for reducing the cargo is to prevent the ships from running aground. The lower level of the lake means the channel is shallower, and the ships must have a shallower draft.
Panama also already has a railroad running parallel to the canal.

I'm surprised you didn't cover any of the North American *existing* alternatives to the Panama route and other potential yet-to-be-built alternatives. For instance, the container port at Tacoma, WA has been the northwestern terminus of the northern railroads for over a century, and primarily serves as a container port for transfer between ships and trains. It also benefits from having a natural deepwater salt-water port (no dredging necessary), and is one of the deepest natural ports in the world.  Seattle also has a strong port capable of assisting with the transfer of containers. And the Salish Sea and Puget Sound are the pinnacle of safe harbors as a large body of saltwater surrounded on 3 sides, with a quarter of a state guarding it from the weather of the ocean, allowing absolutely huge numbers of ships to anchor safely for long periods of time.   Already some 70% of trade from China to the US comes through these western ports (LA and Vancouver as well), and are loaded on to trains for movement through the interior. Adding traffic to and from Europe on those rails would be trivial, rail is extremely efficient cost-wise like cargo ships, and arguably lowers liability for loss of goods while also impacting the environment much less (and has a very real possibility of being fully electrified in the near future).   Jon Talton, a columnist at the Seattle Times, has been writing on the Puget Sound ports for over a decade and has some great articles out covering these topics. There's a lot of focus on cargo staying in cargo ships, but tbh trains are just as effective and have many fewer downsides -- especially when so much of the goods on the seas are making their way between the US and China.   If tariffs with China were to drop, container traffic in west coast ports could explode and completely eclipse the importance of the Panama Canal.

From my understanding, limiting the amount of cargo that each ship is able to carry decreases the displacement of the ship.  This means that more water is actually needed to move the ship through the system (each lock has a finite volume and with lower displacement, more of that volume would need to be filled with water).  The decreased displacement helps with the ship traversing the lake which is shallow.  When there is a water shortage, ships are more likely to get stuck which would cause major delays and expenses.

Anyone who knows anything about logistics knows that floating goods is 10-15x cheaper than running them via truck, not to mention it would probably barely be any quicker, and miles less fuel-efficient. Side note: anyone who thinks lithium ion batteries are going to power the green revolution is not a serious person. They're fine for local, small-scale projects; but to make that happen at scale, we'll need an entirely new battery tech and associated materials science. In my opinion the easiest thing to do is just to build reservoirs along the locks. This is what the (admittedly smaller) locks on the Rhein-Main-Donau Kanal in Germany do. Since they don't have much water entering the canal at its highest point when a ship wants to go down through a lock they simply pump all the water into a concrete tank. When a ship wants to go back up they pump the water back up into the lock. It uses basically zero water and solves the problem.

Going through the Drake Passage is not only longer, its way, way more likely to sink your ship. There's a reason it was feared by mariners of past.
Worth mentioning that the canal is useful and can save millions of $ (and many, many lives of crew members) because Cape Horn is the most dangerous and vioent stretch of ocean on the planet. Many ships that go through there face unreal waves (sometimes surpassing 15-20 meters of height) that travel very fast and are incredibly steep that badly damage the ships and their cargo if they are container carriers, without mentioning the enormous weight that the ice adds to them, as water is sprayed by the waves and immediately frozen all throughout the ships, making them very unstable and prone to sinking.  The clash of the currents from the Southern Ocean with the South Atlantic combined with the immensely powerful winds create some of the most unique and destructive waves on the planet.  Once you go in, you can't turn around, you simply have to proceed. The weather can go from extremely bad and dangerous to straight up deadly in a matter of minutes with no warnings.  The horrific stories that many seafarers have to tell about that passage are heart wrenching to say the least, many of them thought they wouldn't make it out alive because the conditions were just SO bad.  So yeah, it is a very dangerous place to go through, you really do NOT want to go through that passage unless you absolutely have to.
